title: Isaiah Chapter 62 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 62 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 62 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 62.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:1, for whose sake will God not hold His peace?
options: Zion's
Babylon's
Egypt's
Assyria's
questions.correctAnswer: Zion's
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:1 states that God will not hold His peace for Zion's sake.

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:2, who shall see the righteousness of Jerusalem?
options: The Gentiles
The priests
The prophets
The Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:2 states that the Gentiles shall see the righteousness of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What new status is Jerusalem given in Isaiah 62:3?
options: A crown of glory
A desert
A river of peace
A city of gold
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of glory
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:3 says Jerusalem shall be a crown of glory in the hand of the LORD.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:4, what new name will Jerusalem be called?
options: Hephzibah
Shiloh
Jericho
Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Hephzibah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 states Jerusalem shall be called Hephzibah.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 62:5 compare God's rejoicing over Jerusalem to?
options: A bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
A king rejoicing over a victory
A shepherd rejoicing over his sheep
A father rejoicing over a child
questions.correctAnswer: A bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:5 compares God's rejoicing over Jerusalem to a bridegroom rejoicing over the bride.

questions.question: Who are set as watchmen upon the walls of Jerusalem according to Isaiah 62:6?
options: Those who make mention of the LORD
The priests
The elders
The kings
questions.correctAnswer: Those who make mention of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:6 says watchmen are set who make mention of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:7 urges to give God no rest until Jerusalem is made a praise in the earth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:7 commands to give God no rest until He makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:8, what will the LORD no longer give to enemies?
options: Corn and wine
Silver and gold
Land and cattle
Water and oil
questions.correctAnswer: Corn and wine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:8 states the LORD will no more give corn to be meat for enemies nor allow them to drink the wine.

questions.question: Where shall those who have gathered the harvest eat and drink according to Isaiah 62:9?
options: In the courts of holiness
In the fields
In the city gates
In their homes
questions.correctAnswer: In the courts of holiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:9 says those who gathered shall eat and drink in the courts of holiness.

questions.question: What are the people instructed to do in Isaiah 62:10?
options: Prepare the way and cast up the highway
Build houses
Offer sacrifices
Gather gold
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare the way and cast up the highway
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:10 commands to prepare the way of the people and cast up the highway.

questions.question: Which phrase does the LORD proclaim to the end of the world in Isaiah 62:11?
options: Thy salvation cometh
The mountains shall fall
The flood is coming
The earth shall burn
questions.correctAnswer: Thy salvation cometh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:11 says the LORD proclaims 'Thy salvation cometh' to the end of the world.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:12 states the redeemed will be called 'The holy people.'
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:12 calls the redeemed 'The holy people.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:4, what does the name 'Beulah' refer to?
options: The land
The people
The city gates
The temple
questions.correctAnswer: The land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 says the land shall be called Beulah.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:6 says the watchmen will hold their peace day and night.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:6 states the watchmen shall never hold their peace day nor night.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Isaiah 62:1: 'For Zion's sake will I not hold my _______, and for Jerusalem's sake I will not rest.'
options: peace
anger
silence
hand
questions.correctAnswer: peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:1 says 'For Zion's sake will I not hold my peace.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 62 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 62 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 62:1 teach us about perseverance in prayer and faith during difficult times?
options: By encouraging us not to be silent or rest until righteousness and salvation prevail
By advising us to wait quietly and do nothing until God acts
By telling us to rely solely on our own strength to fix problems
By suggesting we focus only on personal needs and ignore others
questions.correctAnswer: By encouraging us not to be silent or rest until righteousness and salvation prevail
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:1 emphasizes persistent prayer and faith, stating God will not hold His peace or rest until righteousness and salvation shine forth. This teaches believers to be persistent and trust in God's timing. See also verses 6-7 about watchmen who never hold their peace.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:2, what does the new name given by the LORD symbolize in the life of a believer?
options: A new identity marked by God's glory and righteousness
A name that shows worldly success
A title given by human leaders
A secret code unknown to others
questions.correctAnswer: A new identity marked by God's glory and righteousness
questions.explanation: The new name given by the LORD represents a transformed identity characterized by righteousness and glory visible to all nations. This encourages believers to reflect God's character in their lives. See also verse 3 about being a crown of glory.

questions.question: What biblical principle about God’s delight in His people is taught in Isaiah 62:4?
options: God delights in His people and calls them by names expressing love and restoration
God is indifferent to the state of His people
God punishes His people without hope
God abandons those who sin
questions.correctAnswer: God delights in His people and calls them by names expressing love and restoration
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 explains that God no longer calls His land 'Forsaken' or 'Desolate' but names it 'Hephzibah' (My delight is in her) and 'Beulah' (Married), showing His delight and restoration. This affirms God's love and faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer struggling with loneliness as a single person asks you for encouragement. Based on Isaiah 62:5, what biblical truth about God's relationship with His people would you share?
options: God rejoices over His people like a bridegroom rejoices over the bride
God is distant and indifferent to their loneliness
God expects them to be alone forever
God only rejoices over the perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God rejoices over His people like a bridegroom rejoices over the bride
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:5 teaches that God rejoices over His people with deep joy, likened to a bridegroom's joy over his bride. This reminds believers that God’s love is intimate and personal, offering comfort in loneliness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 62:6-7 encourage believers to maintain a life of faithful intercession and prayer?
options: By describing watchmen who never hold their peace day and night, urging continual prayer until God establishes Jerusalem
By suggesting prayer only occasionally when convenient
By instructing believers to pray only for their own needs
By telling believers to stop praying after a certain time
questions.correctAnswer: By describing watchmen who never hold their peace day and night, urging continual prayer until God establishes Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 emphasize constant, persistent prayer and intercession by watchmen on Jerusalem's walls who never cease praying until God fulfills His promises, encouraging believers to be diligent in prayer.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 62:8 teach us about honesty and integrity in our work and stewardship?
options: God will protect the fruits of your labor from being taken by enemies or strangers
It is acceptable to let others take credit for your work
One should hide their labor from others
God does not care about how we manage our resources
questions.correctAnswer: God will protect the fruits of your labor from being taken by enemies or strangers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:8 promises God’s protection over the results of faithful labor, reinforcing the importance of honest work and trusting God for provision and protection, encouraging integrity and stewardship.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because their efforts seem unnoticed. Based on Isaiah 62:9, what truth would you share about God's recognition of faithful work?
options: Those who gather and labor will eat and praise the LORD in His holiness
Hard work is never rewarded in this life
God ignores the efforts of His people
Only spiritual leaders receive God's blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Those who gather and labor will eat and praise the LORD in His holiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:9 assures that those who work faithfully will enjoy the fruits of their labor and give praise to God, encouraging perseverance and gratitude for God’s reward.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 62:10 instruct believers in preparing the way for others to come to God?
options: By clearing obstacles and lifting a standard to guide the people
By ignoring the needs of others
By building walls to keep people out
By focusing only on personal salvation
questions.correctAnswer: By clearing obstacles and lifting a standard to guide the people
questions.explanation: Verse 10 calls believers to actively prepare the way for God's people by removing barriers and providing guidance, which teaches practical evangelism and service in the church.

questions.question: What encouragement does Isaiah 62:11 offer about God's salvation and work among His people?
options: Salvation is coming with reward and work before Him
Salvation is uncertain and delayed indefinitely
God's work is hidden and unknowable
Salvation depends on human effort alone
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is coming with reward and work before Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:11 proclaims that God’s salvation is imminent, accompanied by reward and active work, encouraging hopeful trust and readiness in believers.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:12, what names are believers called that reflect their identity in God?
options: The holy people, The redeemed of the LORD, Sought out, A city not forsaken
The lost sheep, The forgotten ones, A city forsaken
The strong and mighty, The rulers of the earth
The hidden ones, The silent people
questions.correctAnswer: The holy people, The redeemed of the LORD, Sought out, A city not forsaken
questions.explanation: Verse 12 declares believers are called holy, redeemed, sought out, and not forsaken, highlighting their secure and honored identity in God, encouraging faith and gratitude.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:4 teaches that God will allow His people to remain forsaken and desolate forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 clearly states that the people will no longer be called Forsaken or Desolate, but will have new names showing God's delight and restoration, affirming hope and renewal.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:6-7 encourages believers to keep silent and give God rest until He acts on their behalf.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 instruct watchmen to never hold their peace and to give God no rest until Jerusalem is established as praise on earth, encouraging persistent prayer and intercession.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 62:3 says you shall be a ______________ of glory in the hand of the LORD, and a royal diadem in the hand of thy God.
options: crown
robe
shield
scepter
questions.correctAnswer: crown
questions.explanation: Verse 3 describes believers as a crown of glory and royal diadem in God’s hand, symbolizing honor and value given by God.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 62:1-2 guide believers in sharing the Gospel with others?
options: By showing that God’s righteousness and glory will be seen by all nations and that believers have a new identity in Him
By encouraging secrecy and silence about faith
By focusing only on Jewish people and ignoring Gentiles
By suggesting that the Gospel is only for kings and rulers
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that God’s righteousness and glory will be seen by all nations and that believers have a new identity in Him
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 affirm that God’s righteousness and salvation will shine so that all nations and kings see it, and believers have a new God-given name, encouraging bold evangelism.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:10, what is a practical way believers can serve their church community?
options: By preparing the way and removing obstacles for others to enter and be welcomed
By creating barriers to keep outsiders away
By focusing only on personal spiritual growth without community involvement
By ignoring the needs of others
questions.correctAnswer: By preparing the way and removing obstacles for others to enter and be welcomed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:10 calls believers to actively prepare the way for the people, symbolizing evangelism and hospitality in the church, encouraging service and inclusion.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 62 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 62.

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:1, what metaphor is used to describe the righteousness of Zion?
options: Brightness
A flowing river
A mighty fortress
A blooming flower
questions.correctAnswer: Brightness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:1 describes Zion's righteousness as going forth 'as brightness,' symbolizing clarity and divine illumination.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:2, what will the Gentiles see concerning Zion?
options: Thy righteousness
Thy wealth
Thy armies
Thy wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Thy righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:2 states that the Gentiles shall see Zion’s righteousness, highlighting the universal recognition of her restored status.

questions.question: What new names will Jerusalem and her land be called as per Isaiah 62:4?
options: Hephzibah and Beulah
Shiloh and Zion
Bethel and Salem
Moriah and Ariel
questions.correctAnswer: Hephzibah and Beulah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 reveals Jerusalem will be called Hephzibah ('My delight is in her') and the land Beulah ('Married'), indicating restoration and divine favor.

questions.question: Isaiah 62:5 draws an analogy between God's rejoicing over Jerusalem and what human relationship?
options: A bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
A father welcoming his child
A king praising his army
A shepherd tending his sheep
questions.correctAnswer: A bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
questions.explanation: The verse uses the marriage metaphor to emphasize God's joyful and intimate relationship with Jerusalem.

questions.question: What role do the watchmen on Jerusalem's walls play according to Isaiah 62:6?
options: They never hold their peace day nor night
They prepare weapons for battle
They collect taxes for the city
They build new gates
questions.correctAnswer: They never hold their peace day nor night
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:6 highlights the watchmen’s ceaseless vigilance and prayer, symbolizing continuous intercession for the city's welfare.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 62:8, the LORD swore by His right hand and His strength that He will no longer give your corn to be _____ for your enemies.
options: meat
tribute
offering
ruin
questions.correctAnswer: meat
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that corn will no longer serve as 'meat' or food for enemies, symbolizing protection and provision.

questions.question: Which imagery in Isaiah 62:10 indicates preparation for a significant arrival or event?
options: Cast up the highway and lift up a standard
Build a tower and gather weapons
Plant vineyards and harvest grapes
Light lamps and spread curtains
questions.correctAnswer: Cast up the highway and lift up a standard
questions.explanation: This imagery reflects preparation for the coming of God's salvation, echoing ancient Near Eastern customs of welcoming royalty or divine presence.

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:11, what has the LORD proclaimed to the ends of the earth?
options: Thy salvation cometh
The day of wrath is near
The temple shall be rebuilt
A new covenant is made
questions.correctAnswer: Thy salvation cometh
questions.explanation: The proclamation announces the nearness of salvation, signifying hope and restoration for Zion.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:3, how is Jerusalem described in relation to the LORD?
options: A crown of glory and a royal diadem
A humble servant and a faithful city
A burning bush and a sacred flame
A mighty fortress and an unshakable rock
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of glory and a royal diadem
questions.explanation: This metaphor conveys Jerusalem’s honored status as precious and glorious in God's hand.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 62:7 instructs the watchmen to give the LORD rest after their prayers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:7 commands the watchmen to give God no rest until Jerusalem is established as a praise in the earth, implying persistent intercession.

questions.question: What is the significance of the names 'Hephzibah' and 'Beulah' in the cultural context of ancient Israel as used in Isaiah 62:4?
options: They signify that the land is beloved and married, indicating restoration and covenantal relationship
They indicate the land is cursed and abandoned, reflecting judgment
They are names of foreign cities symbolizing exile
They refer to historical kings who ruled Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: They signify that the land is beloved and married, indicating restoration and covenantal relationship
questions.explanation: Hephzibah means 'My delight is in her' and Beulah means 'married,' symbolizing God’s renewed covenant love for the land.

questions.question: How does the theme of divine rejoicing over Jerusalem in Isaiah 62:5 connect to New Testament imagery?
options: It parallels the bridegroom's joy over the bride, as seen in Christ's relationship with the Church
It contrasts with the New Testament's emphasis on judgment alone
It is unrelated to New Testament themes
It foreshadows the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the bridegroom's joy over the bride, as seen in Christ's relationship with the Church
questions.explanation: The marriage metaphor in Isaiah 62:5 foreshadows Christ’s loving relationship with the Church, the bride in the New Testament.

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:12, which titles are given to the redeemed people?
options: The holy people and the redeemed of the LORD
The children of Israel and the chosen nation
The exiles and the wanderers
The priests and the Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The holy people and the redeemed of the LORD
questions.explanation: These titles emphasize the sanctified and redeemed status of God's restored people.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Isaiah 62:1-5 that emphasizes God's commitment to Zion?
options: Parallelism and metaphor
Hyperbole and allegory
Irony and sarcasm
Parable and proverb
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism and metaphor
questions.explanation: The passage uses parallelism in phrases and metaphorical language (brightness, marriage) to stress God's unwavering commitment.

questions.question: Isaiah 62:9 speaks of those who have gathered the harvest. What is their response to the LORD?
options: They praise the LORD and drink in His holiness
They hide their harvest to avoid enemies
They offer it as sacrifice to idols
They sell it to foreign merchants
questions.correctAnswer: They praise the LORD and drink in His holiness
questions.explanation: This verse portrays a faithful and joyous worship connected to the fruits of their labor, symbolizing spiritual and physical restoration.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 62 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 62 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:1, what is the Lord's attitude toward Zion and Jerusalem until their righteousness and salvation are fully revealed?
options: He will not hold His peace nor rest
He will wait patiently and quietly
He will only act when called upon
He will punish them until they repent
questions.correctAnswer: He will not hold His peace nor rest
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:1 states that God will not hold His peace nor rest for the sake of Zion and Jerusalem until their righteousness and salvation shine forth. This reflects God's persistent and active commitment, consistent with Psalm 147:2, Romans 8:26, Hebrews 12:3, and Revelation 21:3-4 where God's care and active presence are emphasized.

questions.question: What new identity will Jerusalem receive according to Isaiah 62:2?
options: She shall be called by a new name named by the LORD
She will be known as the city of gold
She will be forgotten among the nations
She will be called the city of war
questions.correctAnswer: She shall be called by a new name named by the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:2 proclaims that Jerusalem will be given a new name by the mouth of the LORD, symbolizing a transformed status and divine favor. This theme of God giving a new name appears also in Revelation 2:17, 3:12, and Genesis 17:5, reflecting God's sovereign authority to redefine His people.

questions.question: In Isaiah 62:3, what metaphor is used to describe Jerusalem's relationship with God?
options: A crown of glory and a royal diadem in the hand of the LORD
A stone rejected by the builders
A barren wilderness
A mighty fortress
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of glory and a royal diadem in the hand of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 3 describes Jerusalem as a crown of glory and royal diadem in God's hand, indicating her preciousness and honored status. This imagery aligns with Old Testament motifs like Psalm 8:5, Exodus 19:6, and New Testament references to believers as a royal priesthood (1 Peter 2:9).

questions.question: What new names will Jerusalem and her land be called according to Isaiah 62:4?
options: Hephzibah and Beulah
Babylon and Sodom
Zion and Salem
Eden and Paradise
questions.correctAnswer: Hephzibah and Beulah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:4 states that Jerusalem will no longer be called Forsaken, but Hephzibah (meaning 'My delight is in her'), and her land Beulah (meaning 'married'), signifying restoration and God's delight. This is consistent with God's covenantal love seen in Hosea 2:19-20 and the marriage metaphor in Ephesians 5:25-27.

questions.question: What analogy does Isaiah 62:5 use to describe God's relationship with Jerusalem?
options: As a bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
As a shepherd tending his sheep
As a father disciplining his child
As a king ruling his kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: As a bridegroom rejoicing over the bride
questions.explanation: Verse 5 uses the analogy of a bridegroom rejoicing over the bride to describe God's joy over Jerusalem, highlighting intimacy and covenantal love. This is echoed in Jeremiah 2:2, Ezekiel 16:8, and the New Testament portrayal of Christ and the Church in Revelation 19:7 and Ephesians 5:25-27.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:6, what role do the watchmen on Jerusalem's walls serve?
options: They keep constant vigilance, never holding their peace day or night
They only watch during the day
They sound an alarm only when enemies approach
They rest at night and work during the day
questions.correctAnswer: They keep constant vigilance, never holding their peace day or night
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:6 emphasizes that the watchmen appointed over Jerusalem will not hold their peace day or night, symbolizing unceasing prayer and intercession. This parallels biblical calls to constant prayer like 1 Thessalonians 5:17 and Luke 18:1.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the watchmen's persistent prayers as described in Isaiah 62:7?
options: To give God no rest until He makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth
To demand immediate judgment on enemies
To seek personal blessings
To avoid God's intervention
questions.correctAnswer: To give God no rest until He makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 7 exhorts the watchmen to give God no rest until He establishes Jerusalem as a praise in the earth, indicating intercessory prayer for divine vindication and restoration. This relates to persistent prayer themes in Luke 18:1-8 and Psalm 122:6.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 62:8, what has the LORD sworn regarding Jerusalem's resources?
options: He will no longer let enemies consume her corn or strangers drink her wine
He will allow enemies to take her resources as a test
He will destroy all her crops as judgment
He will give her resources freely to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will no longer let enemies consume her corn or strangers drink her wine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:8 declares God's oath that Jerusalem's produce will no longer feed enemies or strangers, symbolizing protection and restoration of her blessings. This aligns with God's promises of protection in Deuteronomy 28:8, Psalm 121:7-8, and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: Who will enjoy the fruits of Jerusalem's labor according to Isaiah 62:9?
options: Those who have gathered and brought it, praising the LORD
The enemies who conquered her
The foreign nations
The indifferent bystanders
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have gathered and brought it, praising the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that those who harvest and gather Jerusalem's produce will eat and drink in the courts of God's holiness, praising Him. This reflects God's justice and blessing on the faithful, consistent with Psalm 128:2, John 4:36, and Revelation 7:17.

questions.question: What instructions are given in Isaiah 62:10 concerning the preparation for the people?
options: Go through the gates, prepare the way, cast up the highway, gather stones, and lift a standard
Close the gates and hide the people
Build walls to keep enemies out
Scatter the stones to confuse travelers
questions.correctAnswer: Go through the gates, prepare the way, cast up the highway, gather stones, and lift a standard
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:10 commands preparing the way for the people by clearing and marking a highway, symbolizing open access to salvation. This anticipates messianic preparation similar to John 1:23 and Luke 3:4, where the way is prepared for the Lord.

questions.question: What proclamation does the LORD make to the ends of the earth in Isaiah 62:11?
options: Salvation is coming, His reward is with Him, and His work before Him
War and destruction are imminent
The nations will be scattered
A new king will arise from Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is coming, His reward is with Him, and His work before Him
questions.explanation: Verse 11 proclaims the coming of salvation with the Lord's reward and work before Him, a clear messianic announcement paralleled in Luke 2:30-32, Isaiah 40:3, and Romans 10:15.

questions.question: What titles will be given to the redeemed according to Isaiah 62:12?
options: The holy people, the redeemed of the LORD, and a city not forsaken
The lost and forgotten
The scattered and condemned
The servants of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The holy people, the redeemed of the LORD, and a city not forsaken
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:12 names the redeemed as holy and sought out, emphasizing God's covenant faithfulness. This is consistent with Exodus 19:6, 1 Peter 2:9, and Revelation 14:1 where God's people are sanctified and redeemed.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 62 portray the nature of God's covenant relationship with Jerusalem?
options: As a joyful marriage where God delights in and rejoices over Jerusalem
As a strict legal contract with no affection
As a distant and indifferent lordship
As a temporary arrangement subject to change
questions.correctAnswer: As a joyful marriage where God delights in and rejoices over Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The marriage imagery in Isaiah 62:4-5 shows a covenant marked by delight and joy, reflecting God's faithful and loving commitment to His people, consistent with Hosea 2:19-20, Jeremiah 31:3, and Ephesians 5:25-27.

questions.question: What does the mandate of the watchmen in Isaiah 62 emphasize about the role of prayer in God's redemptive plan?
options: Prayer is persistent and unceasing until God's promises are fulfilled
Prayer is optional and occasional
Prayer is only for personal needs
Prayer should be silent and infrequent
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is persistent and unceasing until God's promises are fulfilled
questions.explanation: Isaiah 62:6-7 shows watchmen praying continually to give God no rest until Jerusalem is established as praise, highlighting persistent intercession, aligned with Luke 18:1, Romans 12:12, and Colossians 4:2.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is conveyed in Isaiah 62:11-12 about salvation?
options: The arrival of salvation with the Lord's reward and the establishment of a redeemed, holy people
The destruction of all nations without exception
The exile of God's people forever
The end of all worship and praise
questions.correctAnswer: The arrival of salvation with the Lord's reward and the establishment of a redeemed, holy people
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 announce the coming salvation and the calling of the redeemed as holy, demonstrating the fulfillment of God's redemptive promises, consistent with Revelation 21:1-4, Isaiah 35:10, and Romans 8:23.
